title: Gattaca
descriptions:
"Gattaca" is a 1997 science fiction film directed by Andrew Niccol, set in a future where genetic engineering is commonplace and has created a society divided by genetic superiority. The plot revolves around the life of Vincent Freeman, a man conceived naturally and born with a high probability of genetic disorders and a predicted short lifespan, a status referred to as "in-valid". In this world, individuals are discriminated against based on their genetic makeup rather than their abilities or achievements. This form of eugenics has created a new underclass of people, and Vincent, with his less-than-ideal genetics, is one of them.

Determined to break free from societal constraints and achieve his dream of traveling to space, Vincent assumes the identity of Jerome Morrow, a "valid" with perfect genetic makeup who has been paralyzed in an accident. Vincent buys Jerome's genetic identity to gain employment at Gattaca Aerospace Corporation, the space agency that launches missions to explore other planets. Jerome provides Vincent with blood, urine, and hair samples to pass Gattaca's rigorous and frequent genetic screenings.

Living a double life, Vincent must meticulously conceal his true identity, meticulously scrubbing away his dead skin and hair, and attaching Jerome's samples to his body to pass the screenings. He is constantly on alert to avoid leaving any trace of his DNA, which could reveal his fraud. Despite these challenges, Vincent excels at Gattaca due to his determination and intellect, not his genetic profile.

As Vincent gets closer to achieving his goal of going on a mission to Titan, one of Saturn's moons, the plot thickens when a mission director at Gattaca is murdered. The ensuing investigation threatens to expose Vincent's secret, as the police find an eyelash that identifies him as an "in-valid". The investigators start closing in on the in-valid who has infiltrated the company.

During this time, Vincent forms a romantic relationship with Irene Cassini, a co-worker who also harbors secrets related to her own genetics. As the investigation intensifies, Vincent's true identity and his relationship with Irene both risk being uncovered. Furthermore, Vincent discovers that the mission director was killed by a valid, further destabilizing the notion that genetic perfection correlates with moral superiority.

The film explores themes of identity, genetic determinism, human spirit, and the ethics of genetic manipulation. It questions the value society places on superficial perfection and whether it can truly measure a person's worth. The tension peaks as Vincent's launch day approaches, and he must confront not only the investigation but also his own brother, Anton, who is part of the police force searching for the "in-valid" at Gattaca.

In the climax of the film, Vincent's ruse is almost exposed, but he is unexpectedly aided by a doctor at Gattaca, who reveals that he has known Vincent's true identity all along. The doctor, who has a son idolizing Vincent's ambition despite being an "in-valid" himself, allows Vincent to proceed with his mission, emphasizing the power of human dreams and aspirations over genetic predisposition.

The film concludes with Vincent finally boarding his spaceship to Titan, having overcome the genetic barriers and prejudices of society through sheer willpower and perseverance. Jerome, who had lived vicariously through Vincent's achievements, chooses to end his life, but not before ensuring that Vincent has enough genetic samples to last a lifetime.

"Gattaca" ends on a note of hope and triumph, as Vincent, the underdog deemed unworthy by society's standards, achieves his impossible dream. The film leaves viewers with a powerful message about the human condition and the potential to transcend the limitations imposed by society and even our biology.
